sentence: Shares of Oracle (ORCL) have quietly risen 20% year-to-date, besting the 7% rise in the S&P 500 index.

The database and cloud giant, which in the third quarter beat Wall Street’s earnings estimates by seven cents, will look to extend the year-long rally Wednesday when it reports fourth quarter fiscal 2017 earnings results after closing bell.
If history holds true, all eyes will be on the company’s cloud business.

Specifically, analysts will want to know how much of Oracle’s total revenue is generated via the cloud where margins are not only higher, but will signal the extent to which Oracle is competing with leaders like Salesforce (CRM) and Microsoft (MSFT).
Likewise, analysts will look for signs that the management is accelerating cloud adoption as the The Redwood City, Calif.-based tech giant continues to transition out of its legacy database business.
For the quarter that ended May, analysts expect Oracle to report adjusted earnings of 78 cents per share on revenue of $10.45 billion.
This compares to the year-ago quarter when earning were 81 cents per share on $10.6 billion in revenue.
For the full year, earnings are projected to be $2.64 per share, up from $2.61 a year ago, while revenue of $37.39 billion would rise about 1% year over year.
Don’t confuse the modest top- and bottom-line forecasts for what is still a strong cash-generating franchise, which delivers between $13 billion to $15 billion annually in cash flow.
What’s more, Oracle is sitting on some $60 billion in cash on the balance sheet.

It’s likely for this reason co-founder, executive chairman and CTO Larry Ellison continues to exert confidence, recently referring to Oracle’s market as being a "burgeoning cloud business.” As such, analysts expect Oracle to post growth of 7.20% in fiscal 2018 along with average annual growth of almost 9% for the next five years.
This means after this year, Oracle’s earnings per share is expected to accelerate.
To that end, while ORCL stock is now trading at near 52-week highs, there’s still an opportunity here for investors with long-term views to capitalize.
From a valuation perspective, you would be hard-pressed to find a better bargain, risk-averse large-cap tech name.
Despite its 52-week high status, ORCL is priced at just 16 times fiscal 2018 estimates of $2.83 per share, versus a forward P/E of 19 for the S&P 500 index.
Assuming ORCL traded on par with the rest of the market, the shares would be valued today at around $52, or 13% higher than current levels.

And with Larry Ellison and CEO Mark Hurd mashing the accelerator towards the Cloud, while actively buying back stock, ORCL could shares could reach $55 in the next 12 to 18 months, delivering some 20% return.
And that’s excellent value, especially when combined with the company’s 1.4% dividend yield.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
